questions.question: Which of the following statements about Bacillus anthracis is wrong?

options.A: B. anthracis colonies give a frosted glass appearance on blood agar
options.B: B. anthracis forms "strings of pearls" on agar with penicillin
options.C: B. anthracis shows more growth at the bottom of gelatin stab cultures
options.D: PLET medium is used to isolate B. anthracis

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) B. anthracis shows more growth at the bottom of gelatin stab cultures. availability, not at the bottom. Blood Culture Morphology: Characteristic Description Blood Agar Large (2 to 5 mm), grey, flat, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular margins, giving a frosted glass appearance . (Option A ruled out) Tenacious consistency firmly adheres to agar. "Medusa head" appearance under microscope. Agar with Penicillin Susceptible to penicillin. Grows large, spherical cells in 3-6 hours on media with 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml. Forms "string of pearls" chains. (Option B ruled out) Gelatin Liquefaction Obligate aerobe. More growth and energy production at the surface. Liquefaction starts from the top, resembling an "inverted fir tree". PLET Medium Contains polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, and thallous acetate in heart infusion agar (PLET) Selective for isolating B. anthracis from samples with other spore-forming bacilli. (Option D ruled out) Serology Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin Test: Detects anthrax antigens in tissue extracts. DFA: Detects antibodies against B. anthracis; confirms presence via cell wall polysaccharide and capsule antigens. Laboratory Safety Note High risk of infection from spores. Caution is advised when handling B.anthracis isolates.

questions.question: A 65 y/o male presents with intense pain, swelling, and a foul-smelling discharge from a rapidly worsening wound on his left foot, accompanied by fever and hypotension. Examination reveals crepitus, skin discolouration, and necrosis. Which of the following is most likely the causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) C. novyi Explanation: C.novyi is an established agent that causes gas gangrene (20-40%) Gas Gangrene Definition: A rapidly spreading, edematous myonecrosis, occurs in association with severely crushed wounds contaminated with pathogenic clostridia, particularly with C. perfringens. Etiological agents Established agents -C.perfirengens (60%), C.novyi and C.septicum(20-40%) (Mnemonic P>S>N) Probable agents - less common- C.bifermentans, C.sordellii (Option C ruled out) C.aerofoetidum, and C.tertium (Option A ruled out) Pathogenesis: gangrene -Pathogenesis" data-author="" data-hash="10201" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="450" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/zcDGQxW5qcQPclXXTSSo1744481632.png" width="450" /> Clinical Manifestations Organism Incubation period C.perferingens 10-48hrs C.septicum 2-3 days C.novyi 5-6 days Excruciating pain at the affected site Foul-smelling thin serosanguineous discharge Gas bubbles (crepitus) in the muscle planes Brawny edema and induration Shock and organ failure develop later Treatment Surgical Debridement - Wide resection of Devitalized tissue Antibiotics- Penicillin + Clindamycin for 10-14 days Hyperbaric oxygen Passive Immunization with anti-alpha toxin antiserum C.difficile causes antibiotic-associated

questions.question: A 65 y/o female presents with severe diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and fever. She has been on clindamycin for the past 10 days to treat a dental infection. O/E, her colonoscopy reveals microabscesses. Stool samples are sent for further testing. Which diagnostic method is considered the gold standard for confirming the suspected infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) ELISA for Toxin Detection Explanations: ELISA for detecting toxins A and/or B in stool samples is considered the gold standard for diagnosing C. difficile infection. This method directly identifies the presence of toxins responsible for the symptoms. Diagnosis 1. Colonoscopy Examination of the colon whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa known as microabscesses. Although it is highly specific, it is not as sensitive as ELISA, hence it is not considered the Gold standard for diagnosis. (Option A ruled out) 2. Culture Stool samples cultured on selective media to identify C. difficile; less sensitive than toxin detection. (Option B ruled out) 3. Toxin Detection ELISA: Detects toxins A and/or B in stool samples, the gold standard. Cell Culture: Toxins produce characteristic effects on Hep-2 or human diploid cell cultures, neutralized by C. sordellii antitoxin. 4. Molecular Methods PCR: Detects genes coding for toxins A and B in stool samples. 5. Histopathology This can be performed with hematoxylin and eosin stains Highly specific but low sensitivity (Option D ruled out) Treatment Antibiotic Discontinuation Stop the antibiotic suspected of contributing to the infection. Antibiotic Therapy Oral vancomycin or metronidazole. Severe cases: Combination of oral vancomycin, intravenous metronidazole, and rectal vancomycin enemas. Prevention Antibiotic Stewardship Limit the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, and fluoroquinolones; prevent disruption of normal gut flora. Infection Control Measures Meticulous hand hygiene and contact precautions in healthcare settings. Recent Treatment Option Fecal Transplants Replenishing gut flora with donated faeces from screened healthy donor

questions.question: A 70 y/o patient with a h/o recent hospitalization for hip replacement surgery presents with watery diarrhoea and abdominal cramping. Physical examination reveals mild abdominal tenderness, and laboratory tests show leukocytosis. Stool examination reveals the presence of Clostridioides difficile toxins. What is the most likely risk factor contributing to this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Prolonged Antibiotic Use Explanation: Prolonged antibiotic use disrupts the normal gut flora, creating an environment conducive to Clostridioides difficile colonization and infection. This patient must have been put on multiple courses of broad-spectrum antibiotics for surgical prophylaxis as well as post-surgery. This is a well-established risk factor for developing pseudomembranous colitis. Pseudomembranous colitis, a severe manifestation of C. difficile infection (CDI), involves: Colon inflammation Formation of whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa. Sized - 1-2mm, or covering extensive areas of the colon. These plaques consist of necrotic leukocytes. Fibrin, Mucus, and Cellular debris Recent Ingestion of Contaminated Food (Option A): While ingestion of contaminated food can lead to foodborne illnesses, it is not a known risk factor specifically for CDI. CDI is primarily associated with disruptions in gut microbiota due to antibiotic use. History of Smoking (Option B): Smoking is not directly associated with an increased risk of Clostridioides difficile infection. Risk factors for CDI include advanced age, recent hospitalization, and antibiotic use. Allergic Reaction to Medications (Option D): While allergic reactions can occur with medications, they do not predispose individuals to Clostridioides difficile infection. CDI is primarily linked to antibiotic-associated disruption of gut microbiota.

questions.question: Which of the following mechanisms primarily contributes to the pathogenicity of Clostridium difficile by disrupting the actin cytoskeleton in cells?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Toxins A and B Explanation: Toxins A (enterotoxin) and B (cytotoxin) are the main toxins produced by C. difficile. They disrupt the actin cytoskeleton by glycosylating GTP-binding proteins, which leads to cell shape loss, reduced cell adhesion, and a weakened epithelial barrier. This disruption is a key factor in the pathogenicity of C. difficile. Spore Production (Option A): While the ability to form spores helps C. difficile survive in the environment and spread, it does not directly disrupt the actin cytoskeleton. This mechanism is more related to the bacterium's durability and ability to infect new hosts. Gene Acquisition (Option C): Gene acquisition, or horizontal gene transfer, refers to obtaining genes from other organisms but, this process itself does not directly disrupt the actin cytoskeleton. Use of Antibiotics (Option D): Long-term antibiotic use disrupts the normal gut microbiota, allowing C. difficile to grow and produce toxins. While this creates a conducive environment for infection, it is not the direct mechanism by which C. difficile disrupts the actin cytoskeleton. Reference: Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 34 Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 270 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 422

questions.question: A 35 y/o man presents to the emergency with a 24-hour history of double vision, difficulty swallowing, and generalised weakness.O/E, has diplopia, a diminished gag reflex, and symmetric descending paralysis. He reports that he recently consumed canned vegetables. Which type of botulism is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Foodborne Botulism Explanation: The patient has a history of consuming canned vegetables and presents with typical symptoms of foodborne botulism, including double vision, difficulty swallowing, and descending paralysis. Foodborne botulism Wound botulism Bottled and canned food (Heat Labile toxins) IP: 12-36 hrs Results in Diplopia Dysphagia Dysarthria Descending Flaccid Paralysis Dilated pupils. GI symptoms are also present. IP: 7-10 days No GI symptoms Infant botulism Iatrogenic botulism Bottle-fed/honey/baby food IP: 1-2 days The first symptom is Constipation. Floppy baby syndrome: flaccid muscles. Surgeries Infant Botulism (Option A): This affects infants under one year old and presents with symptoms like poor feeding, lethargy, and constipation. The patient's age and symptoms do not match this type. Wound Botulism (Option B): This type results from C. botulinum spores contaminating a wound. It presents similarly to foodborne botulism but lacks gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient reports ingestion of home-canned vegetables, which suggests foodborne botulism. Adult Intestinal Botulism (Option D): This is a rare form affecting adults with compromised gut flora, presenting similarly to infant botulism. The patient's history of recent food consumption and acute onset of symptoms makes foodborne botulism more likely.

questions.question: What is the primary mechanism by which Clostridium botulinum acts?

options.A: Invasion and destruction of muscle tissue
options.B: Production of a toxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions
options.C: Induction of an inflammatory response in peripheral nerves
options.D: Production of a toxin that stimulates excessive acetylcholine release

questions.explanation: junctions Correct Answer: B) Production of a toxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions Explanation: Botulinum toxin binds to acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junctions, preventing the release of acetylcholine , which is essential for muscle contraction. This leads to flaccid paralysis, a hallmark of botulism. Invasion and destruction of muscle tissue (Option A): Clostridium botulinum is a non-invasive pathogen, it does not directly destroy muscle tissue. Instead, it exerts its effects through the production of a potent neurotoxin (Botulinum Toxin). Induction of an inflammatory response in peripheral nerves (Option C): Botulinum toxin does not cause an inflammatory response. Its primary action is to block neurotransmitter release, leading to paralysis. Production of a toxin that stimulates excessive acetylcholine release (Option D): The botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum does not stimulate the release of acetylcholine, rather, inhibits it. If the toxin stimulated the release of acetylcholine, it would result in continuous muscle contraction (spastic paralysis), which is contrary to the clinical presentation of botulism. Reference: Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 732 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 397

questions.question: A 30-year-old farmer presents with a deep laceration from a farm tool. His last documented tetanus vaccination was 8 years ago. According to current guidelines, what is the appropriate tetanus prophylaxis for this patient?

options.C: Administer Td complete series and HTIG

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Administer Td vaccine only Explanation: All types of wounds need surgical toilet followed by immunization which depends on the wound type and immunization status of the individual. Tetanus-prone wound: Age of wound > 6 hours, Penetrating wounds (missiles, crush, burn, bite), Depth of wound >1 cm, Presence of devitalized tissue and contaminants (dirt, saliva, etc.) PREVENTION OF TETANUS AFTER INJURY Complete course of vaccine Not tetanus-prone wound Tetanus-prone wound* Taken within 5 years Nothing required Nothing required Taken within >5 to <10 year Td 1 dose Td 1 dose Taken >10 years back Td 1 dose Td 1 dose + HTIG Unknown/incomplete immunization Td complete dose Td complete dose + HTIG Td- Tetanus toxoid and adult diphtheria toxoid HTIG- Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents to the ED with muscle stiffness and spasms. He injured himself with a deep puncture wound while gardening 2 weeks ago; the wound looks necrotic, and he hasn't had a tetanus shot. Lab receives tissue for testing. Which lab finding best indicates Clostridium tetani? broth

options.A: Gram-positive cocci with clusters and no spore formation on microscopy
options.B: Alpha hemolysis on blood agar, with no concentric swarming movement
options.C: Drumstick-shaped terminal spores with black colour and gas production in Robertson’s cooked meat
options.D: Rapid liquefaction of gelatin and no proteolytic reaction in Robertson’s cooked meat broth

questions.explanation: Robertson’s cooked meat broth Correct Answer: C) Drumstick-shaped terminal spores with black colour and gas production in Robertson’s cooked meat broth Explanation: Clostridium tetani is known for its drumstick-shaped terminal spores , which are a hallmark of its identification. Robertson’s cooked meat broth showing black colour and gas production is also characteristic of C. tetani . DIAGNOSIS OF C. TETANI Specimen Necrotic Tissue Microscope examination Drumstick appearance" data-author="CDC/ Dr. Holdeman" data-hash="10213" data-license="OPEN ACCESS" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:12056_lores.jpg" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Pjv4C4OaDvXN1NtprKVB1744483469.png" /> Gram +ve Bacilli Spores with Drumstick appearance - Terminal Spores (Option A ruled out) Blood Agar Alpha hemolysis is produced, which later develops into Beta hemolysis, due to the production of hemolysin (tetanolysin). Concentric movement is seen- Swarming Growth (Option B ruled out) Robertson's Cooked Meat Broth Black colour, gas production Proteolytic reaction (Option D ruled out) Gelatin stab Fir tree appearance Slow liquefaction Fildes Technique To obtain pure colonies of C. tetani A test tube is filled with Nutrient broth, and pure colonies can be isolated from the surface.

questions.question: A 50 y/o woman presents with severe muscle pain and stiffness that began 10 days ago after a minor gardening injury. Initially, she had trouble opening her mouth and swallowing, and now she has generalized muscle spasms with an arched back posture. Her vitals show normal BP but increased HR and sweating. Which of the following is NOT a complication of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Muscle weakness in the extremities Explanation: The case scenario given points to the diagnosis of Tetanus. Muscle weakness, particularly in the extremities, is not typically associated with tetanus. Instead, tetanus is characterized by muscle stiffness and spasms, with hands and feet generally spared Clinical Manifestations Complications Incubation period: 6-10 days A shorter incubation period leads to a graver prognosis Risus sardonicus : Abnormal, sustained spasm of facial muscles producing a grinning appearance (Option A ruled out) Opisthotonos position : Abnormal posture due to generalized spastic contraction of extensor muscles (Option B ruled out) Respiratory muscle spasm: May cause airway obstruction Muscles of the face and jaw are often affected first First symptom : Increase in masseter tone leading to trismus or lockjaw Muscle pain and stiffness Back pain Difficulty in swallowing In neonates: Difficulty in feeding Painful muscle spasm: Localized (affected limb) or generalized Descending spastic paralysis Hands and feet spared, mentation unimpaired Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes Autonomic disturbances during the second week: Low or high BP Tachycardia, sweating Intestinal stasis Increased tracheal secretions Acute renal failure (Option C ruled out)

questions.question: Which of the following statements about tetanospasmin is INCORRECT?

options.A: Tetanospasmin is responsible for the manifestations of tetanus
options.B: Tetanospasmin is antigenic and can be neutralized by its antitoxin
options.C: Tetanospasmin prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA
options.D: Tetanospasmin is used in its active form for vaccine preparation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Tetanospasmin is used in its active form for vaccine preparation. Explanation: Tetanospasmin is not used in its active form for vaccine preparation; it is toxoided (rendered non-virulent) by formaldehyde for use in vaccines. Exotoxin Type Characteristics Tetanolysin Hemolysin Hemolytic activity No role in the Pathogenesis of Tetanus Tetanospasmin Neurotoxin Responsible for tetanus (Option A ruled out) Antigenic; Neutralized by antitoxin (Option B ruled out) Plasmid coded Toxin gets toxoided spontaneously or by formaldehyde. The toxoid form is antigenic but loses its virulence property, hence, it is used for vaccine preparation. Mechanism of Action of Tetanus Toxin: Binds to receptors (polysialogangliosides) on motor nerve terminals, leading to internalization. Transported retrogradely to GABA and glycine-producing inhibitory neuron terminals. Prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine and GABA) . (Option C ruled out) Results in spastic muscle contraction . Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 702 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Page 492

questions.question: A 50 y/o male presents with severe pain, swelling, and crepitus in his left thigh following a traumatic injury. Laboratory tests, including a Nagler's reaction, return positive, indicating a clostridial infection. Which of the following organisms does not test positive for Nagler’s reaction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) C.tetani Explanation: C.tetani produces tetanoplasmin toxin and does not produce alpha toxin. Hence it does not give a positive Nagler reaction Lab diagnosis of C.perferingens 1. Confirmation of clinical diagnosis: Specimen-necrotic tissue, muscle fragments, exudates from deeper parts of the wound Blood culture may be positive for C. perfringens and C. septicum. Direct Microscopy-Absence of neutrophils in the infected tissues is a characteristic feature Organism Microscopic appearance C. Perfringens Thick, stubby, boxcar-shaped, gram-positive bacilli without spore C. septicum Citron bodies ( boat or leaf-shaped pleomorphic irregularly stained bacilli with spores) C. novyi Large rods with oval sub-terminal spores 2. Species Identification Method Properties Robertson cooked meat medium Transport as well as culture media C.perferingens tolerates heat and can grow when incubated at 45°C for 4-6 hrs Shows a pink and turbid appearance Litmus Milk Produces “stormy clot reaction” Fermentation of lactose-producing acid and vigorous gas Nagler’s reaction Produces an opalescence surrounding the streak line on egg yolk agar or media containing 20% human serum (due to lecithinase activity of α -toxin). Opalescence is inhibited by incorporating anti- α -toxin into the medium. Positive for C. bifermentans, C. baratti, and C. sordellii (all produce α -toxin) (Option B, C, D ruled out) Target hemolysis Double zone hemolysis On blood agar, it produces an inner narrow zone of complete hemolysis (due to θ -toxin) Surrounded by a much wider zone of incomplete hemolysis (due to the alpha-toxin) Reverse CAMP test C.perfringens is streaked over the centre of the blood agar plate Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked perpendicular to it The presence of an enhanced zone of hemolysis (arrow-shaped) pointing toward C. perfringens indicates the test is positive

questions.question: A 35 y/o male presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhoea after consuming a large meal of pork. Imaging and laboratory results suggest enteritis necroticans. Which of the following organisms cause enteritis necroticans?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) C. perferingens type C Explanation: Enteritis necroticans is caused by C.perfringens type C strains Clostridial enteric infections: Type of infection Features Food poisoning Caused by C. perfringens type A enterotoxin Consumption of improperly cooked meat Requires 10^8 viable vegetative bacilli for infection to occur. Diagnosis by detection of enterotoxin in faeces Enteritis necroticans Caused by C. perfringens type C strains, producing β toxin Gas gangrene of the bowel Ischemic necrosis of the jejunum and gas in the tissue plane PIGBEL (papa new guinea)- abdominal pain and diarrhoea following unaccustomed feasting on pig meat along with trypsin inhibitors like sweet potatoes. Necrotising enterocolitis C. perfringens type A (Option A ruled out) Resembles enteritis necroticans Gangrenous appendicitis C. perfringens type A Other Clostridial infections Bacteremia: C.perfringens >C.tertium and C.septicum Skin and soft-tissue infections: C.perfringens, C.histolyticum, C.septicum, C.novyi, and C.sordellii cause necrotizing infections of the skin and soft tissues Infection of the endometrium leading to toxic shock syndrome— C. sordellii Meningitis and brain abscess Panophthalmitis (due to C. sordellii or C. perfringens) C.difficle (Option B) causes antibiotic-associated diarrhoea and pseudomembranous colitis. Clostridium tetani (Option D) : It produces a powerful neurotoxin tetanospasmin causing tetanus.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of Bacillus anthracis?

options.B: It produces beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar
options.C: It is generally susceptible to penicillin
options.D: It produces anthrax toxin, which includes protective antigen, oedema factor, and lethal factor

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) It produces beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar. Explanation: Bacillus anthracis forms nonhemolytic or weakly hemolytic colonies on blood agar. In contrast, Bacillus cereus produces strongly beta-hemolytic colonies. Characteristics Bacillus anthracis Bacillus cereus Hemolysis on Sheep Blood Agar Non-hemolytic Hemolytic (Option B) Motility Non-motile (Option A ruled out) Motile Penicillin susceptibility Sensitive (Option C ruled out) Resistant Lecithinase Production + + Gelatin hydrolysis - + Growth in Penicillin agar (10 U/mL) - + Growth on phenyl ethyl alcohol agar - + Bacillus anthracis produces anthrax toxin (Option D) , consisting of three components: protective antigen (PA), oedema factor (EF), and lethal factor (LF). This combination of factors is specific to Bacillus anthracis and is not produced by other Bacillus species. Some Bacillus species include: Bacillus cereus Bacillus thuringiensis Bacillus subtilis Bacillus licheniformis Bacillus circulans Bacillus pumilus Bacillus sphaericus Geobacillus stearothermophilus Bacillus atrophaeus Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 249, 250 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 363,364

questions.question: A 60 y/o male presents with severe pain, swelling, and a foul-smelling discharge from a wound on his leg sustained three days ago.O/E the affected area has signs of necrosis, raising suspicion of gas gangrene. Which of the following toxins is responsible for toxaemia in gas gangrene?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Alpha toxin Explanation: The alpha toxin released by C.perferingens is lethal, dermonecrotic, and hemolytic and is hence responsible for toxaemia in gas gangrene. Virulence Factors - Clostridium Most prolific toxin-producing bacteria Forms 12 different toxins 4 major toxins- alpha, beta, epsilon, and iota and 8 minor toxins It also has enzymes Major Toxin Uses 1. Alpha Most important toxin Responsible for toxemia in gas gangrene Dermonecrotic and hemolytic Naglers reaction - Phospholipase in the presence of Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions split into phosphorylcholine and diglyceride-opalescence in Serum or egg yolk media 2. Beta (Option B ruled out) Lethal and necrotising properties 3. Epsilon 4. Iota Minor toxin Uses 1. Gamma (Option C ruled out) Minor lethal action 2. Eta 3. Delta Lethal effect Hemolytic for the red cells of even-toed ungulates (sheep, goats, pigs, cattle) 4. Theta (Option D ruled out) Oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to streptolysin 0 Lethal and a general cytolytic toxin 5. Kappa Collagenase 6. Lamba Proteinase Gelatinase 7. Mu Hyaluronidase 8. Nu Deoxyribonuclease Enzymes Uses Neuraminidase Destroys myxovirus receptors on RBCs Bursting Factor Specific action on muscle tissue Muscle lesions in gas gangrene Circulating Factor Increase in adrenaline sensitivity of capillary bed Inhibit phagocytosis Haemagglutinin Active against the red blood cells of human beings and most animals Other enzymes include Histamine, Fibrinolysin, hemolysin Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 259 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Page 1003

questions.question: A 58 y/o farmer presented to the casualty with I high fever and chills for the last 5 days.O/E there are no obvious sources of infection. A blood culture was obtained and the patient was diagnosed with PUO. Gram staining revealed characteristic “Tennis racket appearance”. Which of the following is the likely organism causing this infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) C.tertium Explanation: Clostridium tertium on gram staining reveals oval and terminal spores, resembling a tennis racket. Spore formation in Clostridium Spores wider than bacillary body- swollen appearance/spindle-shaped Spore formation occurs in unfavourable conditions Shape and position vary in different species, which helps in the identification of species M/c location -subterminal All species are killed by autoclaving at 121 I for 20 minutes Species Spore position &shape Clostridium perfringens (Option A ruled out) Subterminal -club-shaped Clostridium tetani (Option D ruled out) Spherical and terminal -drumstick Clostridium tertium (Option B) Oval and terminal - tennis racket Clostridium bifermentans (Option C ruled out) Central and oval-spindle-shaped

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Clostridium species is TRUE?

options.A: Most Clostridium species are encapsulated and non-motile
options.B: C. perfringens is both encapsulated and non-motile
options.D: Clostridium species generally exhibit rapid movement due to peritrichate flagella

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) C. perfringens is both encapsulated and non-motile. Explanation: C. perfringens is both encapsulated and non-motile. Characteristic Details Unencapsulated and Motile Most Clostridium species fall into this category (Option A ruled out) Encapsulated Species C. perfringens C. butyricum Non-motile Species C. perfringens (Option C ruled out) C. tetani type VI Motility The majority are motile by peritrichate flagella (flagella attached in multiple locations). (Option D ruled out) This includes C. butyricum. (Option B) Movement described as "stately" due to its slowness (Option D) Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 257

questions.question: A 30 y/o man arrives at the ER with symptoms of food poisoning, including severe nausea and vomiting, after eating fried rice from a local restaurant 5 hours ago. Which statement about Bacillus cereus food poisoning is TRUE? poultry culture

options.A: Symptoms of emetic form typically manifest within 8-16 hours after ingestion
options.B: The emetic form of B. cereus food poisoning is associated with consuming contaminated meat and
options.C: Diagnosis of B. cereus can be confirmed by finding more than >10 5 cells per gram of food or stool
options.D: B. cereus grows anaerobically at 37°C on sheep blood agar

questions.explanation: gram of food or stool culture Correct Answer: C) Diagnosis of Bacillus cereus can be confirmed by finding more than >10 5 cells per gram of food or stool culture. Explanation: Diagnosis of Bacillus cereus food poisoning involves culturing the implicated food or performing quantitative stool cultures, confirming the presence of more than >10 5 bacteria per gram in the absence of other pathogens. Clinical Features of Bacillus cereus: Clinical Features Details Food Poisoning Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic . Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post-ingestion. (Option B ruled out) Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare) Emetic form: Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice; nausea and vomiting within 1-5 hours. (Option A ruled out) Some cases may include diarrhoea Other Infections Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients Diagnosis: Diagnostic Method Details Food Poisoning Culture of implicated food essential. >10 5 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis. Quantitative stool cultures with at least 10 5 cells per gram support diagnosis. Culture Characteristics Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar. (Option D ruled out) β -hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance. Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin Selective Media MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources Microscopy Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli. Motile Reference: Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Page 363, 364 Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 253, 254

questions.question: A 38 y/o biologist returns from a field expedition in an anthrax-endemic area, displaying symptoms and skin lesions indicative of cutaneous anthrax. Lab tests confirm the diagnosis. Which statement about the treatment of cutaneous anthrax is FALSE?

options.A: Oral administration of fluoroquinolones or doxycycline for 7-14 days is recommended
options.B: Combined therapy with antibiotics and anthrax immunoglobulin is necessary
options.C: Human Anthrax Immunoglobulin (Anthrasil) is used as an antitoxin option
options.D: Treatment includes a combination of at least three antimicrobial drugs, including clindamycin

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Combined therapy with antibiotics and anthrax immunoglobulin is necessary. pulmonary and intestinal anthrax due to their higher fatality risk, it is not typically used for uncomplicated cutaneous anthrax, which is often self-limiting and does not require immunoglobulin therapy. Treatment of Anthrax: Clinical Presentation Recommended Treatment Uncomplicated Cutaneous Anthrax Oral fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) or doxycycline for 7-14 days (Option A ruled out) Pulmonary and Intestinal Anthrax Combined therapy with antibiotics and anthrax immunoglobulin due to higher fatality risk Systemic Anthrax Antitoxin treatment alongside antimicrobial drugs to neutralize B. anthracis toxin effects. Antitoxin Options Human Anthrax Immunoglobulin (Anthrasil). (Option C ruled out) Monoclonal Antibodies (Obiltoxaximab, Raxibacumab) Anthrax Meningitis Combination therapy with at least three antimicrobial drugs including clindamycin for 60 days (Option D ruled out) Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) Ciprofloxacin and doxycycline for 60 days. AVA BioThrax vaccine to enhance immune response Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 542 Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 253 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th edition, Page 363

questions.question: A 45 y/o veterinarian presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. He has been working in an area with a recent outbreak of anthrax among livestock. He discusses the precautions he takes and the vaccines available to him. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the precautions and vaccines for Bacillus anthracis?

options.A: Using a biosafety level II/III cabinet is essential.
options.B: Autopsies on animals suspected of anthrax are recommended
options.C: Workers in industries handling animal products should wear protective clothing
options.D: The BioThrax vaccine is considered safe and effective for human use

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Autopsies on animals suspected of anthrax are recommended. Explanation: Autopsies on animals suspected of anthrax are discouraged to prevent soil contamination with spores. Instead, safer alternatives like blood samples or a cut ear are recommended, and proper disposal methods include deep burial in quicklime or cremation. Precautions for Bacillus anthracis: Category Details Biosafety Level Use biosafety level II/III cabinets to handle specimens. (Option A ruled out) Handling Suspected Carcasses Discouraged to prevent soil contamination with spores. Safer alternatives: blood samples or a cut ear. Proper disposal: deep burial in quicklime or cremation Decontamination of Animal Products Decontaminate suspected products via autoclaving. Workers should wear protective clothing and gloves. (Option C ruled out) Duckering Disinfect wool: 2% formaldehyde solution at 30-40°C for 20 minutes. Animal hair and bristles: 0.25% formaldehyde solution at 60°C for six hours Vaccines for Bacillus anthracis: Types of Vaccines Details Live Attenuated, Non-encapsulated Spore Vaccine (Sterne Vaccine) Used in animals. Effective for about one year after a single injection. Not safe for human use Adsorbed (alum-precipitated) Toxoid Vaccine Uses protective antigens to trigger immune response. Safe and effective for human use Eg. BioThrax (Option D ruled out) Pasteur's Anthrax Vaccine Historically significant, Developed by Louis Pasteur in 1881 Mazzucchi Vaccine Uses spores from the attenuated Carbazoo strain combined with 2% saponin Indications and Administration for Bacillus anthracis Vaccination: Category Details Pre-exposure High-risk individuals (e.g., veterinarians, lab personnel). Five-dose regimen followed by boosters Post-exposure Administer alongside antibiotic treatment. For suspected or confirmed inhalation anthrax exposure Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Pages 249 to 253 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition Page 542

A patient presents with a black necrotic lesion on their arm, surrounded by swelling and secondary vesicles. They report handling animal hides recently. What is the most likely diagnosis and the route of transmission?

options.A: Cutaneous anthrax, spores entered through damaged skin

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Cutaneous anthrax, spores entered through damaged skin Explanation: The presentation of a black necrotic lesion (eschar) surrounded by swelling and secondary vesicles is characteristic of cutaneous anthrax, which occurs when Bacillus anthracis spores enter through damaged skin. MO Commonly seen in dock workers carrying hides and skins on their bare backs. Also known as Hide-Porter’s disease. Pulmonary anthrax, inhalation of spores (Option B): Pulmonary anthrax, or Woolsorter's disease, is caused by inhaling spores from contaminated material. It presents as hemorrhagic pneumonia, not a localised skin lesion. Intestinal anthrax, ingestion of spores (Option C): Intestinal anthrax is characterized by severe enteritis with bloody diarrhoea and is associated with consuming contaminated meat. It does not present with a black necrotic skin lesion. Bacillus cereus infection; food poisoning (Option D): Bacillus cereus typically causes food poisoning or other infections like ocular infections, not a black necrotic skin lesion. The patient's recent contact with animal hides and the lesion's characteristics point to cutaneous anthrax. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 249,250 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 361,362 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 540

questions.question: A patient infected with Bacillus anthracis presents with severe oedema and systemic symptoms. Which combination of virulence factors is primarily responsible for these clinical manifestations?

options.B: Protective antigen, oedema factor, and lethal factor

questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Protective antigen, edema factor, and lethal factor Explanation: The clinical manifestations of severe oedema and systemic symptoms are due to the combined action of protective antigen (PA), oedema factor (EF), and lethal factor (LF). PA facilitates the entry of EF and LF into cells, EF causes oedema, and LF contributes to lethality. Polysaccharide capsule and endotoxin (Option A): Bacillus anthracis has a poly-D-glutamic acid (polypeptide) capsule, not a polysaccharide capsule, and does not produce endotoxin. Poly-D-glutamic acid capsule and enterotoxin (Option C): While the poly-D-glutamic acid capsule is a virulence factor, Bacillus anthracis does not produce enterotoxin. The relevant toxin is the anthrax toxin, composed of PA, EF, and LF. Hemolysin and cytotoxin (Option D): Bacillus anthracis does not primarily rely on hemolysin and cytotoxin for its virulence. Its main virulence factors are the poly-D-glutamic acid capsule and the anthrax toxin (PA, EF, and LF). Virulence Factor of Bacillus Anthracis Capsule Exotoxin The capsule is composed of poly-D-glutamic acid, which is different from the polysaccharide capsules found in most other bacteria. It protects against phagocytosis. The capsule is encoded by a plasmid. If this plasmid is lost, the strain will become avirulent. It is composed of protective antigen (PA), oedema factor (EF), and lethal factor (LF). These proteins are nontoxic individually but work together to cause harmful effects. The genes encoding anthrax toxin are carried on a plasmid. PA binds to cell receptors and forms a membrane channel, which allows for the entry of EF and LF into the cell. EF is an adenylate cyclase that causes oedema. LF, when combined with PA, forms a lethal toxin. Lethal toxin is a major virulence factor and is the cause of death in infected people and animal. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 249 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 361

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Bacillus anthracis are true? Bacillus anthracis was the first pathogenic bacterium to be seen under a microscope It was the first communicable disease demonstrated to be transmitted by the inoculation of infected blood It was the first bacillus to be isolated in pure culture and shown to possess spores The anthrax vaccine was the first live attenuated bacterial vaccine prepared.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) All statements are correct Explanation: Bacillus anthracis was the first pathogenic bacterium observed under a microscope by Pollender in 1849. Davaine demonstrated in 1850 that it was the first communicable disease transmitted through inoculation with infected blood. Koch was the first to isolate this bacillus in pure culture and show it possessed spores in 1876. Pasteur created the first live attenuated bacterial vaccine using B. anthracis in 1881. Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 248 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 539 Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 361
